intro: Cyperus gypsophilus, commonly known as the gypsum sedge, is a flowering plant native to arid and semi-arid regions. It belongs to the grass family (Poaceae) and is characterized by its slender, grass-like appearance with narrow leaves. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers arranged in spikelets, which are typically wind-pollinated. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or sandy habitats. Cyperus gypsophilus is adapted to withstand drought conditions, making it a resilient plant in harsh environments.
